examples: he did not want to waste valuable time in idle chatter

verb.description: (of a person) spend time doing nothing; be idle.
examples: four men were idling outside the shop

verb.description: (of an engine) run slowly while disconnected from a load or out of gear.
examples: the car is noisily idling in the street

phrases: As many Internet users do, I sometimes go surfing, following links, idling the happy hours away… you know the drill.

I would never see Grandpa again, never sit on his lap dunking my toast into his sweet coffee, nor follow him to his workshop to mend a rake, nor idle the afternoon away with a scrap of wood and a hammer and nails.
As he idled the afternoon away watching TV, he saw an advertisement promising a free Virgin Atlantic flight to New York to anyone who bought a Hoover.
He is also making great play of the Prince's Trust, appalled as he is by the thought of people idling their days away, never doing an honest day's work in their lives.
The Raiders spent the rest of the night idling their time away beside a roaring campfire.
origin: Old English īdel empty, useless, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch ijdel vain, frivolous, useless and German eitel bare, worthless.
